facts.text: Appellants, three brothers (Laxmipat Choraria, Balchand Choraria and another), convicted under S. 120-B IPC and S. 167(81) Sea Customs Act for conspiracy to smuggle gold into India.
Fourth brother filed Criminal Appeal No. 55 of 1964 but did not press it; S. L. Daga also convicted but did not appeal.
Conspiracy with Yau Mockchi (Chinese citizen in Hong Kong) and others; method: insert 250 tolas gold strips under suitcase lid lining, retrieved by unscrewing supports and pulling strings.
Suitcases brought into India by air stewardesses, including Ethyl Wong (P.W. 1, Anglo-Chinese employed by Air India).

Discovery: Yau Mockchi approached Sophia Wong (O.A.C. line, engaged to police officer); she informed superiors; trap laid; Yau caught with suitcase containing gold after explaining concealment method.

Search of Yau Mockchi and his business: visiting cards including Ethyl Wong and Laxmipat Choraria, photographs of Laxmipat and Balchand Choraria, their addresses, telephone numbers, incriminating letters, accounts, cables.

Raids in India and Hong Kong on Global Agencies run by Kundanmal Choraria and S. L. Daga; numerous documents, codes, account books seized; some photostated; originals returned per Hong Kong Supreme Court order and suppressed.
Prosecution commenced on strength of these materials; Ethyl Wong examined first witness, gave graphic account of conspiracy, her role; admitted accomplice but not prosecuted.
Ethyl Wong carried gold for Yau Mockchi on several occasions; corroborated by Sophia Wong's statement, seized suitcase.
Ethyl Wong's first statement (Ex.1) on Dec 27, 1960 at Bombay Air Terminal; second statement (Ex.2) on Dec 29, 1960 correcting inaccuracies; examined Jan 2, 1961.
Ethyl Wong pointed out flats where she delivered gold; her cable in code to Hong Kong parties; passenger manifests, hotel registers, telephone calls to accused flats.
Offences non-cognizable, investigated by customs officers under Sea Customs Act, not police; complaint by Assistant Collector of Customs.
Letter Z-217 (June 1, 1960) from Balchand's ancestral house at Bidsedar to Begraj Choraria; used for handwriting comparison.
Letters in BC series 1-45 compared with Z-217 to determine Balchand's handwriting.
Ethyl Wong shown photographs of Laxmipat and Balchand at Air Terminal before statement; gave names and descriptions prior.
Documents refer to 'lali' (gold) in tolas, fineness, price; Rolex watch requested and bought; account books show commissions.

legal_issues.text: Whether Ethyl Wong could be examined as a witness and administered oath, being a self-confessed accomplice not arraigned as accused (S.5 Indian Oaths Act).
Whether prosecution bound to try Ethyl Wong jointly or vitiated trial by not doing so (Ss.337, 494 CrPC, S.351 CrPC).
Admissibility of photostats of documents without originals for handwriting comparison.
Validity of Ethyl Wong's identification of Laxmipat and Balchand after being shown photographs.
Whether letter Z-217 proved as in Balchand's handwriting for comparison.
Whether discrimination under Art.14 by selecting Ethyl Wong as witness.

petitioner_arguments.text: Ethyl Wong could not be examined as witness as no oath could be administered (S.5 Oaths Act) since she was accused; self-confessed carrier No.12 in complaint.
Prosecution/Magistrate duty to try Ethyl Wong jointly (S.351 r/w S.91 CrPC); breach vitiates trial; discriminatory.
Photostats without originals inadmissible for handwriting proof.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Indian Evidence Act; McCullough v. Munn; Phipson on Evidence

petitioner_arguments.text: Ethyl Wong's identification worthless as photographs shown prior.
Letter Z-217 not proved in Balchand's handwriting.

respondent_arguments.text: Ethyl Wong competent witness under S.118 Evidence Act; protected by S.132 proviso; not accused as not arraigned.
Accomplice evidence admissible with corroboration (S.133 Evidence Act); no pardon provisions applicable.
respondent_arguments.legal_basis: S.133 Evidence Act; S.337 CrPC inapplicable

respondent_arguments.text: Photostats admissible as originals suppressed; faithful reproductions.
respondent_arguments.legal_basis: Indian Evidence Act S.10; Wigmore on Evidence

respondent_arguments.text: Identification corroborated by independent evidence; names/descriptions given prior.

court_reasoning.text: Ethyl Wong competent witness (S.118 Evidence Act); not accused as not arraigned; bound to answer under S.132; protected from prosecution on her testimony.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Art.20(3) protects accused, not witnesses; voluntary testimony waives privilege.

court_reasoning.text: Accomplice evidence competent (S.133 Evidence Act); received with caution and corroborated.
court_reasoning.key_observation: S.5 Oaths Act exclusion for 'accused person' means one on trial, not investigated suspect.

court_reasoning.text: No duty to try jointly; customs investigation, not police; complaint did not name her definitively.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Magistrate not required to add offenders (S.187A Sea Customs Act).

court_reasoning.text: Photostats admissible where originals suppressed; can prove handwriting if faithful and no trickery.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Modern photography reliable; common in conspiracies.

court_reasoning.text: Identification reliable; prior descriptions, independent corroboration (flats, calls, cards, letters).
court_reasoning.key_observation: Prosecution not solely reliant on photo ID.

court_reasoning.text: Z-217 genuine based on contents, recovery from ancestral home.
No Art.14 violation; selection for witness not arbitrary like S.337 CrPC.
Conspiracy proved beyond doubt; S.10 Evidence Act applies to documents.

holdings.text: Self-confessed accomplice not arraigned is competent witness, can be administered oath; evidence admissible with corroboration.
No vitiation of trial for not trying accomplice jointly where pardon provisions inapplicable.
Photostats of suppressed originals admissible to prove contents and handwriting if faithful.
Prior photo show does not vitiate ID where independently corroborated.

precedents_cited.relevance: Interpretation of 'accused' under S.211 IPC not applicable to Oaths Act.
'Accused' from arrest; not for Oaths Act.
Accomplice not on trial can testify.
Caution on examining accomplice without trial.

precedents_cited.case_name: S. G. Jaisinghani v. Union of India
precedents_cited.relevance: Art.14 not violated by accomplice selection.

statutes_cited.name: Indian Penal Code
statutes_cited.relevance: Conspiracy offence; S.10 Evidence Act attracted.

statutes_cited.name: Indian Evidence Act
statutes_cited.relevance: Conspiracy evidence; competency of witnesses and accomplices; protection for self-incriminating testimony.

statutes_cited.name: Indian Oaths Act
statutes_cited.relevance: No oath to accused unless for defence; accomplice not accused.

statutes_cited.name: Code of Criminal Procedure
statutes_cited.relevance: Pardon, joint trial, influence on accused; inapplicable here.

statutes_cited.name: Constitution of India
statutes_cited.relevance: No discrimination; no self-incrimination for witnesses.

outcome.summary: Appeals against conviction and sentences under S.120B IPC and S.167(81) Sea Customs Act dismissed; evidence of accomplice Ethyl Wong held admissible and sufficiently corroborated; conspiracy proved by overwhelming evidence including documents and acts; sentences not interfered with given gravity of gold smuggling.

key_quotes.text: "Under S. 118 of the Indian Evidence Act all persons are competent to testify unless the court considers that they are prevented from understanding the questions put to them..."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Establishes general competency of witnesses including accomplices.

key_quotes.text: "The evidence of Ethyl Wong cannot, therefore, be ruled out as that of an incompetent witness."
key_quotes.speaker: court

key_quotes.text: "If the photostats were not available this prosecution would have been greatly jeopardised."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Justifies use of photostats in conspiracy cases.

key_quotes.text: "There is such overwhelming evidence of the complicity of the appellants that when the points of law fail there is very little to be said in their favour."
key_quotes.speaker: court
